justification: The paper uses the 4-in-a-row game as a tool to investigate planning, with players' Elo ratings and in-game behavior serving as measures of planning effectiveness. The computational cognitive model predicts planning behavior, which is linked to a player's skill level.

measured_by: Planning depth, feature drop rate, heuristic quality metrics
justification: The study derives three metrics from the cognitive model—planning depth, feature drop rate, and heuristic quality—to analyze expertise. These metrics are directly linked to players' Elo ratings and their decision-making proficiency, validated through laboratory and mobile app experiments.

The feature drop rate measures the probability of attentional lapses during decision-making. Lower feature drop rates are associated with increased planning depth and expertise, indicating players' ability to maintain focus on relevant board features.

The heuristic quality metric reflects the precision of players' value function when evaluating board states. Improvement in this metric is linked with increased playing strength, as players develop more accurate assessments of game positions.

The memory and reconstruction experiment reveals that experts exhibit improved pattern recognition skills compared to novices. Experts accurately reconstruct game-relevant features more quickly, suggesting a strong link between pattern recognition and planning depth.

measured_by: Computational model parameters (feature weights, decision tree size, pruning threshold, etc.)
justification: The accuracy of the computational model in predicting human behavior is validated through experiments. The model parameters, such as feature weights and decision tree size, effectively capture different aspects of human planning during the game.
